title: quarto tabset
text:
create tabset panel
::: {.panel-tabset}

## Tabset A
```{.python}
import polars as pl
print('polars version:', pl.__version__)
```

## Tabset B 
```{.python}
import pandas as pd
print('pandas version:', pd.__version__)
```

:::


use polars df in plotlyuse pandas df in plotly



import polars as pl
import plotly.express as px

wide_df = pl.DataFrame(
    {
        "nation": ["South Korea", "China", "Canada"],
        "gold": [24, 10, 9],
        "silver": [13, 15, 12],
        "bronze": [9, 12, 12],
    }
)

fig = px.bar(
    wide_df,
    x="nation",
    y=["gold", "silver", "bronze"],
    title="Wide-Form Input"
)

fig.show()

                                                





import plotly.express as px

df = px.data.iris()

# Use directly Columns as argument. You can use tab completion for this!
fig = px.scatter(
    df,
    x=df.sepal_length,
    y=df.sepal_width,
    color=df.species,
    size=df.petal_length
)

fig.show()

                                                







expand code block and its output to full screen width

import polars as pl
csv_path = "./data/tw_taoyuan_cankun_merged_updated.csv"
df = pl.read_csv(csv_path)
df.head(5)

title: quarto tabset
text:
::::

use polars df in plotlyuse pandas df in plotly



import polars as pl
import plotly.express as px

wide_df = pl.DataFrame(
    {
        "nation": ["South Korea", "China", "Canada"],
        "gold": [24, 10, 9],
        "silver": [13, 15, 12],
        "bronze": [9, 12, 12],
    }
)

fig = px.bar(
    wide_df,
    x="nation",
    y=["gold", "silver", "bronze"],
    title="Wide-Form Input"
)

fig.show()


                                                





import plotly.express as px

df = px.data.iris()

# Use directly Columns as argument. You can use tab completion for this!
fig = px.scatter(
    df,
    x=df.sepal_length,
    y=df.sepal_width,
    color=df.species,
    size=df.petal_length
)

fig.show()

title: show the underlying data strucure of a plotly fig
text:
import plotly.express as px

fig = px.line(
    x=["a","b","c"],
    y=[1,3,2],
    title="sample figure"
)
fig.show()

                                                




print(fig)fig.to_dict()fig.to_json()


print(fig) will result in the often-verbose layout.template key being represented as ellipses ... for brevity.

print(fig)      # opt 1
# fig.to_dict()   # opt 2
# fig.to_json()   # opt 3

Figure({
    'data': [{'hovertemplate': 'x=%{x}<br>y=%{y}<extra></extra>',
              'legendgroup': '',
              'line': {'color': '#636efa', 'dash': 'solid'},
              'marker': {'symbol': 'circle'},
              'mode': 'lines',
              'name': '',
              'orientation': 'v',
              'showlegend': False,
              'type': 'scatter',
              'x': array(['a', 'b', 'c'], dtype=object),
              'xaxis': 'x',
              'y': array([1, 3, 2]),
              'yaxis': 'y'}],
    'layout': {'legend': {'tracegroupgap': 0},
               'template': '...',
               'title': {'text': 'sample figure'},
               'xaxis': {'anchor': 'y', 'domain': [0.0, 1.0], 'title': {'text': 'x'}},
               'yaxis': {'anchor': 'x', 'domain': [0.0, 1.0], 'title': {'text': 'y'}}}
})





# print(fig)      # opt 1
fig.to_dict()   # opt 2
# fig.to_json()   # opt 3
